quotes.text: A man who has not passed through the inferno of his passions has never overcome them.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that confronting and experiencing one's deepest passions and struggles is essential for truly overcoming and understanding them.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: Every form of addiction is bad, no matter whether the narcotic be alcohol or morphine or idealism.
quotes.explanation: Jung warns against any form of addiction, whether it is to substances or even seemingly positive ideals, as it can lead to a loss of balance and self-control.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: The privilege of a lifetime is to become who you truly are.
quotes.explanation: This quote encourages individuals to embrace their true selves, seeing self-discovery and authenticity as the greatest achievements one can strive for in life.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: I am not what happened to me, I am what I choose to become.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes personal agency and resilience, asserting that one's identity and future are shaped by choices and actions rather than past experiences.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: One does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious.
quotes.explanation: Enlightenment, according to Jung, comes not from wishful thinking but from confronting and understanding the darker aspects of oneself.
quotes.reference: Psychology and Alchemy

quotes.text: Everything that irritates us about others can lead us to an understanding of ourselves.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that our reactions to others often reflect our own unresolved issues, and understanding these reactions can provide insight into our own psyche.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: As far as we can discern, the sole purpose of human existence is to kindle a light in the darkness of mere being.
quotes.explanation: Jung speaks to the existential quest for meaning, suggesting that humans are meant to bring understanding and illumination to the darker, unknown aspects of existence.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: The greatest tragedy of the family is the unlived lives of the parents.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the impact of unfulfilled potential and dreams on family dynamics, suggesting that parents' unactualized lives can have profound effects on their children.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Man needs difficulties; they are necessary for health.
quotes.explanation: Jung asserts that challenges and obstacles are essential for personal growth and psychological well-being, pushing individuals to develop resilience and strength.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: The pendulum of the mind oscillates between sense and nonsense, not between right and wrong.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that the human mind continuously shifts between rationality and irrationality, rather than strictly between correct and incorrect, highlighting the complexity of human thought.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: There is no coming to consciousness without pain.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes that self-awareness and growth often come through difficult and painful experiences, which are necessary for true understanding and consciousness.
quotes.reference: Psychology and Alchemy

quotes.text: The shoe that fits one person pinches another; there is no recipe for living that suits all cases.
quotes.explanation: Jung points out the individuality of human experience, suggesting that what works for one person may not work for another, and that each person must find their own path.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: Who looks outside, dreams; who looks inside, awakes.
quotes.explanation: This quote underscores the importance of self-reflection and introspection. Jung suggests that true understanding and enlightenment come from looking within oneself rather than focusing solely on external realities.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 11: Psychology and Religion: West and East

quotes.text: Until you make the unconscious conscious, it will direct your life and you will call it fate.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the power of the unconscious mind and the need to bring unconscious thoughts and desires to conscious awareness to gain control over one's life and destiny.
quotes.reference: Aion: Researches into the Phenomenology of the Self

quotes.text: Your vision will become clear only when you look into your heart. Who looks outside, dreams; who looks inside, awakes.
quotes.explanation: Reiterating the importance of inner exploration, Jung asserts that clarity and true vision come from understanding one's inner self rather than relying on external validation.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 11: Psychology and Religion: West and East

quotes.text: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances: if there is any reaction, both are transformed.
quotes.explanation: This quote highlights the profound impact of human interactions. Jung compares the interaction between people to a chemical reaction, emphasizing how such encounters can lead to significant personal transformation.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Knowing your own darkness is the best method for dealing with the darknesses of other people.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that by understanding and accepting one's own flaws and darker aspects, one can better empathize with and support others in their struggles.
quotes.reference: Psychology and Alchemy

quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the uniqueness of individual experiences and the importance of personalizing one's approach to life. There is no one-size-fits-all solution to living; what works well for one person may not be suitable for another. This underscores the need for self-awareness and individualized approaches to personal and mental health.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Your vision will become clear only when you look into your heart. Who looks outside, dreams; who looks inside, awakes.
quotes.explanation: Jung asserts that true clarity and understanding come from introspection rather than external observation. By turning inward and examining one's own heart and motivations, individuals can achieve a deeper level of self-awareness and enlightenment, as opposed to merely dreaming about possibilities seen outside of oneself.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 11: Psychology and Religion: West and East

quotes.text: Every form of addiction is bad, no matter whether the narcotic be alcohol or morphine or idealism.
quotes.explanation: Jung cautions against any form of addiction, whether it is to substances like alcohol and morphine or to seemingly noble concepts like idealism. Addictions of any kind can become detrimental, leading to a loss of balance and preventing individuals from living a healthy and integrated life.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances: if there is any reaction, both are transformed.
quotes.explanation: Jung uses the metaphor of a chemical reaction to describe the transformative potential of human interactions. When two people connect, they have the potential to influence and change each other profoundly, leading to mutual growth and transformation.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Knowing your own darkness is the best method for dealing with the darknesses of other people.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the importance of self-awareness in dealing with others' flaws and challenges. By recognizing and understanding one's own dark aspects, individuals can better empathize with and support others, leading to more compassionate and effective relationships.
quotes.reference: Psychology and Alchemy

quotes.text: One does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light, but by making the darkness conscious.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that true enlightenment and self-awareness come from confronting and understanding the darker parts of the psyche. Rather than merely fantasizing about positive outcomes, it is essential to acknowledge and integrate the shadow aspects of the self.
quotes.reference: Psychology and Alchemy

quotes.text: The privilege of a lifetime is to become who you truly are.
quotes.explanation: Jung encourages individuals to embrace their authentic selves. The ultimate goal in life, according to him, is self-discovery and self-acceptance, leading to a fulfilling and genuine existence.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: A man who has not passed through the inferno of his passions has never overcome them.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that it is necessary to confront and experience one's deepest passions and struggles in order to truly overcome and understand them. Avoiding these challenges prevents personal growth and mastery over one's inner demons.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: Everything that irritates us about others can lead us to an understanding of ourselves.
quotes.explanation: Jung points out that our reactions to others often reflect our own unresolved issues. By examining what irritates us in others, we can gain insight into our own psyche and work towards resolving these internal conflicts.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: The pendulum of the mind oscillates between sense and nonsense, not between right and wrong.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the complexity of human thought, suggesting that the mind constantly swings between rationality and irrationality, rather than strictly between right and wrong. This reflects the nuanced nature of human cognition and the challenges of maintaining a balanced perspective.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.explanation: Jung asserts that facing challenges and difficulties is essential for personal growth and psychological well-being. These obstacles push individuals to develop resilience, strength, and a deeper understanding of themselves.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: As far as we can discern, the sole purpose of human existence is to kindle a light in the darkness of mere being.
quotes.explanation: Jung speaks to the existential quest for meaning, suggesting that humans are meant to bring understanding and illumination to the darker, unknown aspects of existence. This pursuit of knowledge and self-awareness is seen as the fundamental purpose of life.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: The greatest tragedy of the family is the unlived lives of the parents.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the impact of unfulfilled potential and dreams on family dynamics. When parents do not pursue their own passions and aspirations, it can lead to a sense of regret and lost opportunities, which may negatively affect their children and family relationships.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: A man who has not passed through the inferno of his passions has never overcome them.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that it is necessary to confront and experience one's deepest passions and struggles in order to truly overcome and understand them. Avoiding these challenges prevents personal growth and mastery over one's inner demons.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: People will do anything, no matter how absurd, to avoid facing their own souls.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that individuals often go to great lengths to avoid confronting their own inner issues and truths. This avoidance can lead to irrational behavior, highlighting the importance of self-reflection and facing one's own soul for genuine personal growth.
quotes.reference: Psychology and Alchemy

quotes.text: In all chaos there is a cosmos, in all disorder a secret order.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the idea that beneath apparent chaos and disorder lies a hidden structure or order. This perspective can provide comfort and insight, suggesting that there is meaning and organization even in life's most confusing moments.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 9 (Part 1): The Archetypes and The Collective Unconscious

quotes.text: The most terrifying thing is to accept oneself completely.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the profound difficulty and fear associated with fully accepting oneself, including one's flaws and darker aspects. This acceptance is crucial for true self-understanding and personal integration.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: A dream that is not understood remains a mere occurrence; understood, it becomes a living experience.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that dreams hold valuable insights into the unconscious mind. By understanding and interpreting dreams, they can become meaningful experiences that contribute to personal growth and self-awareness.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 8: Structure & Dynamics of the Psyche

quotes.text: The healthy man does not torture others – generally it is the tortured who turn into torturers.
quotes.explanation: Jung posits that those who inflict harm on others often do so because of their own unresolved pain and suffering. This insight fosters empathy and understanding, emphasizing the importance of addressing one's own wounds to prevent harm to others.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: We cannot change anything unless we accept it. Condemnation does not liberate, it oppresses.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the power of acceptance in facilitating change. By accepting reality and oneself, individuals can achieve liberation and transformation, whereas condemnation only leads to further oppression and stagnation.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances: if there is any reaction, both are transformed.
quotes.explanation: Jung uses the metaphor of a chemical reaction to describe the transformative potential of human interactions. When two people connect, they have the potential to influence and change each other profoundly, leading to mutual growth and transformation.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Who has fully realized that history is not contained in thick books but lives in our very blood?
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the idea that history is not merely a record of past events but is deeply ingrained in our very being. This quote encourages a deeper understanding of how historical experiences shape and influence us on a fundamental level.
quotes.reference: The Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 8: Structure & Dynamics of the Psyche

quotes.text: The creative mind plays with the objects it loves.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that creativity stems from a place of love and playful engagement. The creative process is driven by an intrinsic passion and affection for the objects or subjects one works with.
quotes.reference: Psychological Types

quotes.text: Every form of addiction is bad, no matter whether the narcotic be alcohol or morphine or idealism.
quotes.explanation: Jung warns against all forms of addiction, whether to substances or ideas. Such dependencies can be detrimental to one's mental health and overall balance, highlighting the need for moderation and self-awareness.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: Man needs difficulties; they are necessary for health.
quotes.explanation: Jung asserts that facing challenges and difficulties is essential for personal growth and psychological well-being. These obstacles push individuals to develop resilience, strength, and a deeper understanding of themselves.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

This reflects the nuanced nature of human cognition and the challenges of maintaining a balanced perspective.

quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes that personal growth and self-awareness often come through difficult and painful experiences. These challenges are necessary for achieving true understanding and consciousness, leading to deeper insights and maturity.
quotes.reference: Psychology and Alchemy

quotes.text: The least of things with a meaning is worth more in life than the greatest of things without it.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the importance of meaning and purpose. Even small things imbued with significance are more valuable than grand but meaningless achievements.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: A man who has not passed through the inferno of his passions has never overcome them.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that it is necessary to confront and experience one's deepest passions and struggles in order to truly overcome and understand them. Avoiding these challenges prevents personal growth and mastery over one's inner demons.

quotes.text: Knowing your own darkness is the best method for dealing with the darknesses of other people.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the importance of self-awareness in dealing with others' flaws and challenges. By recognizing and understanding one's own dark aspects, individuals can better empathize with and support others, leading to more compassionate and effective relationships.
quotes.reference: Psychology and Alchemy

quotes.text: Thinking is difficult, that’s why most people judge.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that thoughtful reflection requires effort, which is why many people opt for quick judgments instead. This quote encourages deeper contemplation and understanding rather than superficial assessments.
quotes.reference: The Essential Jung: Selected Writings

quotes.text: You are what you do, not what you say you'll do.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the importance of actions over words. True character and intentions are revealed through one's actions rather than mere promises or statements.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: Shame is a soul-eating emotion.
quotes.explanation: Jung identifies shame as a destructive emotion that can erode one's sense of self and well-being. Addressing and overcoming shame is crucial for mental and emotional health.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Show me a sane man and I will cure him for you.
quotes.explanation: Jung challenges the concept of normalcy and sanity, suggesting that everyone has complexities and irrationalities. This quote invites a reevaluation of what it means to be 'sane' and encourages acceptance of human imperfection.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 16: The Practice of Psychotherapy

quotes.text: Where wisdom reigns, there is no conflict between thinking and feeling.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that true wisdom harmonizes thought and emotion. When wisdom is present, there is a balance between rational thinking and emotional experience, leading to a more integrated and peaceful state of mind.
quotes.reference: Psychological Types

quotes.text: The least of things with a meaning is worth more in life than the greatest of things without it.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the importance of meaning and purpose. Even small things imbued with significance are more valuable than grand but meaningless achievements.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: What you resist, persists.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that resisting or denying difficult emotions or situations often makes them more persistent. Acceptance and confrontation are essential for overcoming and resolving internal conflicts.
quotes.reference: Memories, Dreams, Reflections

quotes.text: We cannot change anything until we accept it. Condemnation does not liberate, it oppresses.
quotes.explanation: Jung emphasizes the power of acceptance in creating change. Condemning or rejecting parts of oneself or reality only leads to further oppression, whereas acceptance can lead to liberation and transformation.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Even a happy life cannot be without a measure of darkness, and the word 'happiness' would lose its meaning if it were not balanced by sadness.
quotes.explanation: Jung highlights the duality of human experience, suggesting that happiness and sadness are interdependent. The presence of some darkness and sadness gives depth and meaning to happiness, making it more appreciable.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Where love rules, there is no will to power; and where power predominates, there love is lacking. The one is the shadow of the other.
quotes.explanation: Jung contrasts love and power, suggesting that they are mutually exclusive forces. Where love is present, there is no desire to dominate, and where power seeks to dominate, love is absent. Each reveals the shadow of the other, highlighting the need for balance and the dangers of prioritizing power over love.
quotes.reference: Collected Works of C.G. Jung, Volume 10: Civilization in Transition

quotes.text: To ask the right question is already half the solution of a problem.
quotes.explanation: Jung underscores the importance of asking the right questions in problem-solving. Formulating a good question directs attention and thought in productive ways, often leading to clearer and more effective solutions.
quotes.reference: Modern Man in Search of a Soul

quotes.text: Thinking is difficult, that’s why most people judge.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that thoughtful reflection requires effort, which is why many people opt for quick judgments instead. This quote encourages deeper contemplation and understanding rather than superficial assessments.
quotes.reference: The Essential Jung: Selected Writings

quotes.text: The beginning is the most important part of the work.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the importance of starting any task or project well, as the beginning sets the tone and foundation for everything that follows.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book II

quotes.text: Wise men speak because they have something to say; fools because they have to say something.
quotes.explanation: Plato distinguishes between the thoughtful communication of the wise and the unnecessary chatter of fools, highlighting the value of meaningful speech.
quotes.reference: Phaedrus

quotes.text: The measure of a man is what he does with power.
quotes.explanation: This quote reflects on the true nature of a person being revealed when they are given power, emphasizing integrity and moral character in leadership.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IX

quotes.text: The greatest wealth is to live content with little.
quotes.explanation: Plato suggests that true wealth lies in being satisfied with what one has, rather than constantly seeking more, thus finding contentment in simplicity.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VIII

quotes.text: Ignorance, the root and stem of all evil.
quotes.explanation: This quote highlights the idea that ignorance is the fundamental cause of wrongdoing, stressing the importance of knowledge and awareness.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VII

quotes.text: Courage is knowing what not to fear.
quotes.explanation: Plato defines true courage as understanding which fears are rational and which are not, encouraging wise and discerning bravery.
quotes.reference: Laches

quotes.text: At the touch of love, everyone becomes a poet.
quotes.explanation: This quote expresses the idea that love has the power to inspire creativity and beauty in everyone, revealing deep emotions and artistry.
quotes.reference: Symposium

quotes.text: The direction in which education starts a man will determine his future life.
quotes.explanation: Plato underscores the profound impact of early education on an individual's future, emphasizing the importance of proper guidance and learning from a young age.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: An empty vessel makes the loudest sound, so they that have the least wit are the greatest babblers.
quotes.explanation: Plato observes that those with little knowledge often speak the most, drawing a parallel between an empty vessel making more noise than a full one.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book III

quotes.text: The soul takes nothing with her to the next world but her education and her culture.
quotes.explanation: This quote highlights the enduring value of education and cultural development, suggesting that these are the only true possessions that follow us beyond life.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book X

quotes.text: There are three classes of men: lovers of wisdom, lovers of honor, and lovers of gain.
quotes.explanation: Plato categorizes people based on their primary pursuits, identifying philosophers, warriors, and businessmen, each motivated by different desires.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IX

quotes.text: He who is not a good servant will not be a good master.
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that effective leadership requires the experience and humility gained from serving others, highlighting the importance of empathy and understanding.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Knowledge which is acquired under compulsion obtains no hold on the mind.
quotes.explanation: Plato argues that learning forced upon someone is ineffective, as true understanding and retention require genuine interest and voluntary engagement.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VII

quotes.text: Human behavior flows from three main sources: desire, emotion, and knowledge.
quotes.explanation: Plato identifies the primary drivers of human actions, emphasizing the interplay between desires, emotions, and knowledge in shaping behavior.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Good actions give strength to ourselves and inspire good actions in others.
quotes.explanation: This quote underscores the ripple effect of positive actions, suggesting that doing good not only empowers us but also motivates others to act similarly.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VI

quotes.text: And when they have made a good beginning in play, and by the help of music have gained the habit of good order, then this habit of order, in a manner how unlike the lawless play of the others! will accompany them in all their actions and be a principle of growth to them
quotes.explanation: Socrates emphasizes the importance of early education in shaping character. He suggests that the habits formed through structured play and music education will influence all aspects of a person's life. This highlights the long-term impact of childhood experiences on adult behavior and social order.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Until some one rare and grand result is reached which may be good, and may be the reverse of good?
quotes.explanation: This quote acknowledges the uncertainty in educational and social experiments. Socrates recognizes that even well-intentioned efforts can have unpredictable outcomes, both positive and negative. It suggests a need for caution and careful observation when implementing new social or educational policies.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: And without divine help, said Adeimantus, they will go on for ever making and mending their laws and their lives in the hope of attaining perfection.
quotes.explanation: This statement reflects the Greek belief in the limitations of human wisdom. It suggests that without divine guidance, people will endlessly attempt to improve their laws and lives, never reaching perfection. This idea emphasizes the complexity of governance and the potential futility of constant reform without higher wisdom.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Yes, I said, and you may add my suffrage to Damon's and your own.
quotes.explanation: This quote shows Socrates agreeing with the importance of maintaining traditional forms of music. It reflects the belief that music has a profound influence on character and society, and that changes in musical styles could have far-reaching effects on the state.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Then, as I was saying, our youth should be trained from the first in a stricter system, for if amusements become lawless, and the youths themselves become lawless, they can never grow up into well-conducted and virtuous citizens.
quotes.explanation: Socrates argues for a structured approach to youth education and activities. He believes that allowing too much freedom in childhood leads to lawlessness in adulthood. This reflects a view that discipline and order in early life are crucial for developing good citizens.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: It would seem, Adeimantus, that the direction in which education starts a man, will determine his future life. Does not like always attract like?
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the lasting impact of early education on a person's life trajectory. Socrates suggests that the initial direction of one's education shapes their future choices and associations. It underscores the critical importance of early educational experiences in determining life outcomes.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Well, and about the business of the agora, and the ordinary dealings between man and man, or again about agreements with artisans; about insult and injury, or the commencement of actions, and the appointment of juries, what would you say?
quotes.explanation: Socrates questions the need for extensive laws governing everyday interactions and commerce. This reflects his belief that a well-ordered society with properly educated citizens might require minimal legal regulation of daily life, trusting in the good character of its people.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: You would compare them, I said, to those invalids who, having no self-restraint, will not leave off their habits of intemperance?
quotes.explanation: This analogy compares those who constantly seek to reform laws to ill people who refuse to change their unhealthy habits. It suggests that continual legislative changes without addressing fundamental societal issues is like treating symptoms without curing the underlying disease.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: For are there not ill-ordered States in which the citizens are forbidden under pain of death to alter the constitution; and yet he who most sweetly courts those who live under this regime and indulges them and fawns upon them and is skilful in anticipating and gratifying their humours is held to be a great and good statesman
quotes.explanation: Socrates criticizes states that rigidly enforce unchanging laws while rewarding politicians who pander to public whims. This highlights the tension between stability and adaptability in governance, and the dangers of political flattery over genuine leadership.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: I conceive, I said, that the true legislator will not trouble himself with this class of enactments whether concerning laws or the constitution either in an ill-ordered or in a well-ordered State; for in the former they are quite useless, and in the latter there will be no difficulty in devising them
quotes.explanation: Socrates argues that a truly wise lawmaker won't focus on minor regulations. In a poorly-run state, such laws are ineffective; in a well-run state, they're unnecessary or easily created. This suggests that good governance relies more on overall societal order and citizen virtue than on extensive legal codes.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: There seem to be two causes of the deterioration of the arts... Wealth, I said, and poverty.
quotes.explanation: Socrates argues that both wealth and poverty can lead to the decline of craftsmanship and skills. This insight suggests that moderation and balance are key to maintaining quality in work and life.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Wealth, I said, and poverty; the one is the parent of luxury and indolence, and the other of meanness and viciousness, and both of discontent.
quotes.explanation: This quote expands on the previous point, showing how extremes of wealth or poverty can lead to negative character traits and social problems. It emphasizes the importance of economic balance in society.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Silver and gold we neither have nor are permitted to have, but you may; do you therefore come and help us in war, and take the spoils of the other city
quotes.explanation: This hypothetical diplomatic message illustrates Socrates' idea of a state that values virtue and skill over material wealth. It suggests that such a state would be more formidable in war.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Any city, however small, is in fact divided into two, one the city of the poor, the other of the rich; these are at war with one another
quotes.explanation: This insight recognizes the inherent class conflict within cities, suggesting that economic inequality leads to social division and conflict.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Let our city be accounted neither large nor small, but one and self-sufficing.
quotes.explanation: Socrates advocates for a balanced, self-sufficient state rather than one focused on expansion or comparison with others. This reflects his belief in moderation and unity.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Education, I said, and nurture: If our citizens are well educated, and grow into sensible men, they will easily see their way through all these, as well as other matters
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the fundamental importance of education in creating a well-functioning society. Socrates believes that good education can solve many social and political problems.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Any musical innovation is full of danger to the whole State, and ought to be prohibited.
quotes.explanation: This controversial statement reflects Socrates' belief in the power of art to influence society. He argues for cultural conservatism to maintain social stability.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Until some one rare and grand result is reached which may be good, and may be the reverse of good?
quotes.explanation: This quote acknowledges the uncertainty of outcomes in education and social engineering. It suggests that even well-intentioned efforts can have unexpected results.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: I shall not attempt to legislate further about them.
quotes.explanation: Socrates recognizes the limits of legislation, especially regarding minor social customs. This shows his belief that some aspects of society should develop organically rather than through top-down control.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Nothing to us, I replied; but to Apollo, the God of Delphi, there remains the ordering of the greatest and noblest and chiefest things of all.
quotes.explanation: This statement reflects the Greek reverence for divine wisdom, suggesting that the most important aspects of governance should be guided by higher principles or divine inspiration.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: And do you not suppose, Adeimantus, that our youth should be trained from the first in a stricter system, for if amusements become lawless, and the youths themselves become lawless, they can never grow up into well-conducted and virtuous citizens.
quotes.explanation: Socrates emphasizes the importance of a structured educational system for youth. He argues that allowing too much freedom in childhood can lead to lawlessness in adulthood, suggesting that early discipline is crucial for developing good citizens.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Then beauty of style and harmony and grace and good rhythm depend on simplicity,—I mean the true simplicity of a rightly and nobly ordered mind and character, not that other simplicity which is only an euphemism for folly?
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that true beauty in art and character stems from genuine simplicity and noble mindedness, not from naivety or foolishness. It emphasizes the connection between inner virtue and outward expression.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book IV

quotes.text: Until philosophers are kings, or the kings and princes of this world have the spirit and power of philosophy, and political greatness and wisdom meet in one, and those commoner natures who pursue either to the exclusion of the other are compelled to stand aside, cities will never have rest from their evils,—no, nor the human race, as I believe,—and then only will this our State have a possibility of life and behold the light of day.
quotes.explanation: This famous quote argues for the union of political power and philosophical wisdom. Socrates suggests that only when rulers are philosophers, or philosophers become rulers, can a state truly flourish and overcome its problems.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book V

quotes.text: The true lover of knowledge is always striving after being—that is his nature; he will not rest in the multiplicity of individuals which is an appearance only, but will go on—the keen edge will not be blunted, nor the force of his desire abate until he have attained the knowledge of the true nature of every essence by a sympathetic and kindred power in the soul.
quotes.explanation: This passage describes the philosopher's relentless pursuit of truth and understanding. It suggests that true philosophers are not satisfied with superficial knowledge but seek to comprehend the essence of things.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VI

quotes.text: And have we not a right to say in his defence, that the true lover of knowledge is always striving after being—that is his nature; he will not rest in the multiplicity of individuals which is an appearance only, but will go on—the keen edge will not be blunted, nor the force of his desire abate until he have attained the knowledge of the true nature of every essence by a sympathetic and kindred power in the soul, and by that power drawing near and mingling and becoming incorporate with very being, having begotten mind and truth, he will have knowledge and will live and grow truly, and then, and not till then, will he cease from his travail.
quotes.explanation: This extended quote elaborates on the nature of the true philosopher, describing their unceasing quest for understanding and union with truth. It portrays philosophy as a transformative journey that leads to genuine knowledge and personal growth.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VI

quotes.text: And those who govern ought not to be lovers of the task? For, if they are, there will be rival lovers, and they will fight.
quotes.explanation: Socrates argues that rulers should not be overly attached to power. He suggests that those who love ruling for its own sake might compete destructively, implying that good leaders should view their role as a duty rather than a privilege.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VII

quotes.text: But then, if I am right, certain professors of education must be wrong when they say that they can put a knowledge into the soul which was not there before, like sight into blind eyes.
quotes.explanation: This quote challenges the idea that education is about inserting knowledge into empty minds. Instead, it suggests that education is more about drawing out and developing the inherent capacities of the learner.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VII

quotes.text: And therefore calculation and geometry and all the other elements of instruction, which are a preparation for dialectic, should be presented to the mind in childhood; not, however, under any notion of forcing our system of education.
quotes.explanation: Socrates advocates for early education in mathematics and geometry as a foundation for philosophical thinking. However, he cautions against a forceful approach, suggesting that education should be engaging rather than coercive.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VII

quotes.text: Then, my dear Glaucon, I said, do not use compulsion, but let early education be a sort of amusement; you will then be better able to find out the natural bent.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the importance of making early education enjoyable. Socrates suggests that a playful approach to learning can help reveal a child's natural inclinations and talents.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VII

quotes.text: And so, Glaucon, I said, we have at last arrived at the hymn of dialectic. This is that strain which is of the intellect only, but which the faculty of sight will nevertheless be found to imitate; for sight, as you may remember, was imagined by us after a while to behold the real animals and stars, and last of all the sun himself. And so with dialectic; when a person starts on the discovery of the absolute by the light of reason only, and without any assistance of sense, and perseveres until by pure intelligence he arrives at the perception of the absolute good, he at last finds himself at the end of the intellectual world, as in the case of sight at the end of the visible.
quotes.explanation: This passage describes dialectic as the highest form of intellectual pursuit, comparing it to the journey of sight from shadows to real objects and finally to the sun. It suggests that philosophical reasoning can lead to the understanding of absolute truths.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book VII

quotes.text: Then, if women are to have the same duties as men, they must have the same nurture and education?
quotes.explanation: Socrates proposes equal education and roles for women, a revolutionary idea for his time. This suggests that capability, not gender, should determine one's place in society.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book V

quotes.text: And when we have given them the same education which we give to men, must we not admit that we shall be giving them the same duties and the same sphere of action?
quotes.explanation: This quote further reinforces the idea of gender equality in education and societal roles. It challenges traditional gender norms by suggesting that equal education leads to equal capabilities and responsibilities.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book V

quotes.text: The guardian must be wise, and he must be strong, and he must be swift and agile.
quotes.explanation: Socrates outlines the ideal qualities of a guardian in his perfect state. This emphasizes the importance of a well-rounded character combining intellectual and physical virtues for those in positions of power.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book II

quotes.text: And he who cannot bear to do this, whether at the writing of verses or in speech or in action, must be made to say so.
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that honesty and integrity are crucial, even when it's difficult. It emphasizes the importance of admitting one's limitations or disagreements, rather than pretending or deceiving.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book III

quotes.text: For this feeling of wonder shows that you are a philosopher, since wonder is the only beginning of philosophy.
quotes.explanation: Socrates links the feeling of wonder to the philosophical mindset. This suggests that curiosity and a sense of awe at the world are fundamental to philosophical inquiry and learning.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book V

quotes.text: Then the good is not the cause of all things, but of the good only?
quotes.explanation: This quote challenges the idea that a supreme good is responsible for everything. It suggests a more nuanced view of causality and morality, where good is responsible only for good things.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book II

quotes.text: And therefore, I said, Glaucon, musical training is a more potent instrument than any other, because rhythm and harmony find their way into the inward places of the soul.
quotes.explanation: Socrates emphasizes the profound impact of music on character formation. This reflects the Greek belief in the power of art to shape the soul and influence moral development.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book III

quotes.text: And when a beautiful soul harmonizes with a beautiful form, and the two are cast in one mould, that will be the fairest of sights to him who has an eye to see it?
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that true beauty is a harmony of inner virtue and outer appearance. It reflects the Greek ideal of 'kalos kagathos', where physical and moral beauty are united.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book III

quotes.text: Then we shall be right in getting rid of the lamentations of famous men, and making them over to women (and not even to women who are good for anything), or to men of a baser sort, that those who are being educated by us to be the defenders of their country may scorn to do the like.
quotes.explanation: Socrates argues against excessive emotional displays, particularly from leaders. This reflects the Greek ideal of stoicism and self-control, especially for those in positions of power or responsibility.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book III

quotes.text: And therefore we must assume a control over the narrators of this class of tales as well as over the others, and beg them not simply to revile but rather to commend the world below, intimating to them that their descriptions are untrue, and will do harm to our future warriors.
quotes.explanation: This quote discusses the importance of controlling narratives about death and the afterlife. Socrates suggests that overly negative portrayals could harm the courage of future defenders, emphasizing the role of cultural narratives in shaping societal values.
quotes.reference: The Republic, Book III

quotes.text: The tree of life is probably, first of all, a fruit-bearing genealogical tree, that is, a mother-image. Countless myths prove the derivation of man from trees; many myths show how the hero is enclosed in the maternal tree—thus dead Osiris in the column, Adonis in the myrtle, etc.
quotes.explanation: This highlight discusses the tree of life as a mother symbol in mythology, showing how heroes are often associated with or enclosed in trees, representing a maternal image.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The sexual libido regressing to the parents appears as the incest tendency. The reason this path is so easily travelled is due to the enormous indolence of mankind, which will relinquish no object of the past, but will hold it fast forever.
quotes.explanation: Jung explains how the concept of incest in mythology and psychology relates to the human tendency to cling to the past, particularly to parental figures.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The Dioscuri represent a similar idea, although in a somewhat different form; the one sun is always mortal, the other immortal. As this entire sun mythology is merely a psychologic projection to the heavens, the fundamental thesis probably is as follows; just as man consists of a mortal and immortal part, so the sun is a pair of brothers, one being mortal, the other immortal.
quotes.explanation: This passage discusses the concept of duality in sun mythology, relating it to the human psyche's mortal and immortal aspects.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: Man as an individual is a suspicious phenomenon, the right of whose existence from a natural biological standpoint could be seriously contested, because, from this point of view, the individual is only a race atom, and has a significance only as a mass constituent.
quotes.explanation: Jung challenges the significance of individual existence from a biological standpoint, suggesting that humans may only have meaning as part of a larger collective.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The religious myth meets us here as one of the greatest and most significant human institutions which, despite misleading symbols, nevertheless gives man assurance and strength, so that he may not be overwhelmed by the monsters of the universe.
quotes.explanation: This highlight emphasizes the importance of religious myths in providing humans with psychological strength and assurance in the face of life's uncertainties.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The primitive power which Job's Hymn of Creation vindicates, the unconditional and inexorable, the unjust and the superhuman, are truly and rightly attributes of libido, which 'lead us unto life,' which 'let the poor be guilty,' and against which struggle is in vain.
quotes.explanation: Jung relates the concept of libido to primitive power as described in the Book of Job, suggesting its overwhelming and inescapable nature.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The Sphinx, in its traditional form, is a half-human, half-animal creature, which we must, in part, interpret in the way that is applicable to such phantastic products.
quotes.explanation: This passage introduces the interpretation of the Sphinx as a symbolic creature, bridging human and animal natures.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The city is a maternal symbol, a woman who fosters the inhabitants as children. It is, therefore, intelligible that the two mother goddesses, Rhea and Cybele, both wear the wall crown.
quotes.explanation: Jung explains the symbolism of cities as maternal figures in mythology and psychology.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The conflict, which is the condition of every neurosis, is lacking. The resistance against loving produces the inability to love.
quotes.explanation: This highlight discusses the relationship between internal conflict, resistance, and the capacity for love in the context of neurosis.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The sacrifice of the horse: sacrifice of the animal nature—The sacrifice of the 'mother libido': of the son to the mother—Superiority of Christian symbol: the sacrifice, not only of lower nature, but the whole personality
quotes.explanation: Jung compares different forms of symbolic sacrifice in various religions, highlighting the comprehensiveness of the Christian symbol.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The power of incest prohibition created the self-conscious individual—It was the coercion to domestication
quotes.explanation: This passage suggests that the incest taboo played a crucial role in the development of self-consciousness and human civilization.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The regression resulting from the incest prohibition leads, in this case, to the new valuation of the mother; this time, however, not as a sexual object, but as a nourisher.
quotes.explanation: Jung discusses how the incest prohibition leads to a transformation in the perception of the mother figure, from a sexual object to a nurturing one.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The discovery of fire seems to be due to a very similar regression to the presexual stage, more particularly to the nearest stage of the displaced rhythmic manifestation.
quotes.explanation: This highlight connects the discovery of fire to psychological regression, linking cultural evolution to individual psychological development.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: Man tries to sneak into rebirth through subterfuge in order to become a child again.
quotes.explanation: Jung interprets certain mythological themes as representing a universal human desire to return to a state of childhood innocence.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The complex is robbed by that of the personal element.... This tendency towards dissolution (transformation) of every individual complex is the motive for poetry, painting, for every sort of art.
quotes.explanation: This passage suggests that the process of transforming personal complexes into less personal forms is the basis for artistic creation.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: Christianity, with its repression of the manifest sexual, is the negative of the ancient sexual cult.
quotes.explanation: Jung proposes that Christianity can be seen as an inversion of ancient fertility cults, repressing what was once openly celebrated.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The resistance against sexuality aims, therefore, at preventing the sexual act; it also seeks to crowd the libido away from the sexual function.
quotes.explanation: This highlight discusses how psychological resistance to sexuality can lead to the redirection of libido away from its original sexual function.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The Cabiri are chtonian divinities, who, in the mysteries, were worshipped in Samothrace. The mysteries of the Cabiri are referred to as orgies, and are said to have resembled those of the mother of the gods.
quotes.explanation: Jung discusses the Cabiri, ancient deities associated with fertility and mystery cults, drawing connections between different mythological traditions.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The libido which lies inactive in the incestuous bond repressed and in fear of the law and the avenging Father God can be led over into sublimation through the symbol of baptism (birth from water) and of generation (spiritual birth) through the symbol of the descent of the Holy Ghost.
quotes.explanation: Jung explains how religious symbols can help transform repressed libido into spiritual experiences.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The sun mounts like a goat to the highest mountain, and later goes into the water as a fish. The fish is the symbol of the child, for the child before his birth lives in the water like a fish, and the Sun, because it plunges into the sea, becomes equally child and fish.
quotes.explanation: This passage illustrates the symbolic connections between the sun, goat, fish, and child in various mythologies.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The chest, basket or little basket, with its precious contents, was thought of as floating on the water; a remarkable inversion of the natural fact that the child floats in the amniotic fluid and that this is in the uterus.
quotes.explanation: Jung points out how mythological symbols often invert natural processes, specifically in relation to birth and water symbolism.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The libido afflux probably accounts for the enormous interest in this act. The child sees that this is the way in which something is produced, in which something comes out.
quotes.explanation: This highlight discusses the child's fascination with excretion as a metaphor for creation and production.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The vision following upon that of the city is that of a 'strange fir tree with gnarled branches.' This vision does not seem extraordinary to us after all that we have learned of the tree of life and its associations with the city and the waters of life.
quotes.explanation: Jung interprets a vision of a tree, connecting it to the broader symbolism of the tree of life in various mythologies.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The simple negation of the symbol changes nothing, for the entire mental disposition remains the same; we merely remove the dangerous object. But the object is not dangerous; the danger is our own infantile mental state.
quotes.explanation: Jung argues that simply rejecting symbols doesn't solve psychological issues; the real problem lies in our immature mental state.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The moral danger lies in belief in the symbol because through that we guide the libido to an imaginary reality.
quotes.explanation: This passage warns about the dangers of overly literal belief in symbols, which can lead to a disconnection from reality.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: I think belief should be replaced by understanding; then we would keep the beauty of the symbol, but still remain free from the depressing results of submission to belief.
quotes.explanation: Jung suggests that understanding symbols, rather than blindly believing in them, can preserve their value without their negative effects.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The creation by the eternal thought is nothing but a human conception of the sexual act projected into the cosmic.
quotes.explanation: This highlight suggests that human understanding of creation is often a projection of sexual concepts onto a cosmic scale.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The fire-bringer is always a culture-hero. But the fact that fire is so closely connected with the sex libido (not with sexuality in itself) is demonstrated by the phallic symbols of the fire-bringer.
quotes.explanation: Jung connects the mythological figure of the fire-bringer with sexual symbolism and cultural development.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The repression of the incest wish appears to be a biological necessity, because without this inhibition the family would be entirely destroyed, and with it one of the strongest and most essential foundations of society.
quotes.explanation: This passage explains the societal importance of the incest taboo from a biological and psychological perspective.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The phantastic thinking corresponds to the dream state of humanity; the myth is the mass dream of the people, and the dream is the myth of the individual.
quotes.explanation: Jung draws parallels between individual dreams and collective myths, suggesting they serve similar psychological functions.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The infantile psyche, even in the adult, pursues exclusively the gratification of its wishes; in its phantasy it remains caught in its earliest hopes and struggles.
quotes.explanation: This highlight discusses how aspects of the adult psyche retain childlike characteristics, particularly in relation to wish fulfillment.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The hero myth is an unconscious drama seen only in projection, like the happenings in Plato's parable of the cave.
quotes.explanation: Jung interprets the hero myth as a projection of unconscious psychological processes, comparing it to Plato's allegory of the cave.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The beauty of religion is that it makes us children again. The bitter-sweet theme of Paradise Lost contains this idea.
quotes.explanation: This passage suggests that religion allows adults to reconnect with a childlike state, relating this to the theme of Paradise Lost.
quotes.reference: Psychology of the Unconscious by Carl Jung

quotes.text: The Will to Truth, which is to tempt us to many a hazardous enterprise, the famous Truthfulness of which all philosophers have hitherto spoken with respect, what questions has this Will to Truth not laid before us! What strange, perplexing, questionable questions!
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche introduces the concept of 'Will to Truth', questioning its implications and challenging traditional philosophical approaches. He suggests that this drive for truth might lead us into dangerous territories, hinting at the potential risks of relentlessly pursuing truth without considering its consequences.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: It is difficult to be understood, especially when one thinks and lives gangasrotogati among those only who think and live otherwise—namely, kurmagati, or at best 'froglike,' mandeikagati (I do everything to be 'difficultly understood' myself!)
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche reflects on the difficulty of being understood when one's thinking differs significantly from others. He uses Sanskrit terms to illustrate different speeds of thought, suggesting that profound thinkers operate at a different pace from the majority. This highlights the isolation that innovative thinkers might experience.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: Every select man strives instinctively for a citadel and a privacy, where he is FREE from the crowd, the many, the majority—where he may forget 'men who are the rule,' as their exception
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche discusses the tendency of exceptional individuals to seek isolation from the masses. This reflects his belief in the importance of individuality and the potential conflict between innovative thinkers and societal norms. It also hints at his concept of the 'übermensch' or superior individual.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: What is most difficult to render from one language into another is the TEMPO of its style, which has its basis in the character of the race, or to speak more physiologically, in the average TEMPO of the assimilation of its nutriment.
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche explores the challenges of translation, particularly in conveying the rhythm and style of language. He connects this to cultural and physiological factors, suggesting that language is deeply rooted in a people's way of life and thinking. This reflects his interest in the relationship between culture, language, and thought.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: It has gradually become clear to me what every great philosophy up till now has consisted of—namely, the confession of its originator, and a species of involuntary and unconscious auto-biography
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche suggests that all great philosophies are essentially personal expressions of their creators, rather than objective truths. This idea challenges the notion of philosophical objectivity and implies that understanding a philosophy requires understanding the philosopher's personal context and motivations.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: There is a point in every philosophy at which the 'conviction' of the philosopher appears on the scene; or, to put it in the words of an ancient mystery: Adventavit asinus, Pulcher et fortissimus.
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche humorously points out that even in the most rigorous philosophies, there comes a point where the philosopher's personal beliefs become evident. The Latin phrase, meaning 'The donkey arrives, beautiful and very strong', suggests that these personal convictions might be seen as stubborn or foolish when scrutinized.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: The eagerness and subtlety, I should even say craftiness, with which the problem of 'the real and the apparent world' is dealt with at present throughout Europe, furnishes food for thought and attention
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche comments on the contemporary philosophical debates about reality and appearance. He suggests that there might be hidden motives or agendas behind these discussions, hinting at his skepticism towards traditional metaphysics and his interest in uncovering the psychological roots of philosophical inquiries.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: Supposing that nothing else is 'given' as real but our world of desires and passions, that we cannot sink or rise to any other 'reality' but just that of our impulses—for thinking is only a relation of these impulses to one another
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche proposes a radical perspective on reality, suggesting that our desires and passions might be the only true reality we can know. This challenges traditional philosophical views of objective reality and emphasizes the role of subjective experience and drives in shaping our understanding of the world.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: Everything that is profound loves the mask: the profoundest things have a hatred even of figure and likeness. Should not the CONTRARY only be the right disguise for the shame of a God to go about in?
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche discusses the tendency of profound truths to hide themselves. He suggests that the most divine or significant truths might appear in the most unexpected or contradictory forms, challenging our assumptions about how truth presents itself and encouraging a more nuanced approach to understanding.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: A new order of philosophers is appearing; I shall venture to baptize them by a name not without danger. As far as I understand them, as far as they allow themselves to be understood—for it is their nature to WISH to remain something of a puzzle—these philosophers of the future might rightly, perhaps also wrongly, claim to be designated as 'tempters.'
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche introduces the idea of a new type of philosopher, one who challenges established truths and resists easy understanding. By calling them 'tempters', he suggests they will lead people away from comfortable certainties, encouraging a more critical and adventurous approach to thinking.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: In the philosopher, on the contrary, there is absolutely nothing impersonal; and above all, his morality furnishes a decided and decisive testimony as to WHO HE IS
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche emphasizes the personal nature of philosophy, suggesting that a philosopher's moral views are a direct reflection of their character and experiences. This challenges the idea of philosophy as an objective, impersonal pursuit and ties into his view of philosophy as autobiography.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: The fundamental belief of metaphysicians is THE BELIEF IN ANTITHESES OF VALUES. It never occurred even to the wariest of them to doubt here on the very threshold (where doubt, however, was most necessary)
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche critiques the tendency of philosophers to think in terms of absolute opposites. He suggests that this binary thinking is a fundamental flaw in traditional metaphysics, hinting at his own philosophy which often emphasizes the complexities and ambiguities between apparent opposites.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: There are still harmless self-observers who believe that there are 'immediate certainties'; for instance, 'I think,' or as the superstition of Schopenhauer puts it, 'I will'
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche challenges the idea of 'immediate certainties' in philosophy, specifically targeting Descartes' 'I think' and Schopenhauer's 'I will'. He suggests that these supposedly self-evident truths are actually complex assumptions, foreshadowing later philosophical developments in phenomenology and existentialism.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: As far as the superstitions of logicians are concerned, I will never tire of emphasizing a small, terse fact, which is unwillingly recognized by these credulous minds—namely, that a thought comes when 'it' wishes, and not when 'I' wish
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche questions the common assumption of control over our thoughts, suggesting instead that thoughts arise independently of our will. This challenges notions of free will and conscious control, anticipating later psychological theories about the unconscious and the limits of self-knowledge.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: Every profound spirit needs a mask; nay, more, around every profound spirit there continually grows a mask, owing to the constantly false, that is to say, SUPERFICIAL interpretation of every word he utters, every step he takes, every sign of life he manifests
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche discusses the idea that deep thinkers often need to conceal their true nature, either deliberately or as a result of being misunderstood. This reflects his views on the isolation of great thinkers and the difficulty of communicating profound ideas in a society that tends towards superficial understanding.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: The falseness of an opinion is not for us any objection to it: it is here, perhaps, that our new language sounds most strangely. The question is, how far an opinion is life-furthering, life-preserving, species-preserving, perhaps species-rearing
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche challenges the traditional view that truth is the highest value, suggesting instead that the value of an idea should be judged by its practical effects on life and human flourishing. This reflects his pragmatic approach to truth and his critique of absolute moral values.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: To recognize untruth as a condition of life; that is certainly to impugn the traditional ideas of value in a dangerous manner, and a philosophy which ventures to do so, has thereby alone placed itself beyond good and evil.
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche proposes that accepting untruth as necessary for life is a radical philosophical stance that goes beyond conventional morality. This idea challenges the foundational assumptions of Western philosophy and ethics.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: It is perhaps just dawning on five or six minds that natural philosophy is only a world-exposition and world-arrangement (according to us, if I may say so!) and NOT a world-explanation
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche suggests that natural philosophy (science) doesn't truly explain the world, but rather describes and organizes it according to human perspectives. This critiques scientific positivism and foreshadows later philosophies of science.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: Psychologists should bethink themselves before putting down the instinct of self-preservation as the cardinal instinct of an organic being. A living thing seeks above all to DISCHARGE its strength--life itself is WILL TO POWER
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche introduces his concept of 'Will to Power', arguing that it's more fundamental than self-preservation. This idea becomes central to his philosophy, suggesting that the drive to express and expand one's power is the basic motivation of all life.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: In short, we believe that the intention is only a sign or symptom, which first requires an explanation--a sign, moreover, which has too many interpretations, and consequently hardly any meaning in itself alone
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche challenges the importance placed on intentions in moral philosophy, suggesting that they are merely symptoms of deeper drives and are often ambiguous. This critique targets Kant's ethics and foreshadows later developments in moral psychology.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: There is a point in every philosophy at which the 'conviction' of the philosopher appears on the scene; or, to put it in the words of an ancient mystery: Adventavit asinus, Pulcher et fortissimus.
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche humorously suggests that every philosophy, no matter how rational it appears, ultimately rests on the personal convictions of the philosopher. This challenges the notion of philosophical objectivity and hints at the personal nature of all thought.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: It seems to me that there is everywhere an attempt at present to divert attention from the actual influence which Kant exercised on German philosophy, and especially to ignore prudently the value which he set upon himself.
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche critiques the contemporary reception of Kant's philosophy, suggesting that Kant's true influence and self-evaluation are being overlooked. This reflects Nietzsche's interest in the personal and historical aspects of philosophical ideas.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: Let it be permitted to designate by this expression the belief which regards the soul as something indestructible, eternal, indivisible, as a monad, as an atomon: this belief ought to be expelled from science!
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche argues against the traditional concept of the soul as an indivisible, eternal entity. This challenges both religious and philosophical notions of the self, advocating for a more scientific and naturalistic approach to understanding human psychology.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: The spell of certain grammatical functions is ultimately also the spell of physiological valuations and racial conditions.
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche suggests that the structure of language influences our thinking and reflects deeper physiological and cultural conditions. This idea anticipates later developments in linguistic relativity and the philosophy of language.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: The desire for 'freedom of will' in the superlative, metaphysical sense, such as still holds sway, unfortunately, in the minds of the half-educated, the desire to bear the entire and ultimate responsibility for one's actions oneself, and to absolve God, the world, ancestors, chance, and society therefrom, involves nothing less than to be precisely this CAUSA SUI, and, with more than Munchausen daring, to pull oneself up into existence by the hair, out of the slough of nothingness.
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche critiques the concept of absolute free will, arguing that it's an impossible and self-contradictory idea. He suggests that this desire for total self-determination is a form of self-deception, ignoring the many factors that influence our actions.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: All psychology hitherto has run aground on moral prejudices and timidities, it has not dared to launch out into the depths.
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche criticizes previous approaches to psychology for being limited by moral assumptions. He advocates for a more radical and honest exploration of human psychology, foreshadowing developments in psychoanalysis and depth psychology.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: Every select man strives instinctively for a citadel and a privacy, where he is FREE from the crowd, the many, the majority--where he may forget 'men who are the rule,' as their exception
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche discusses the tendency of exceptional individuals to seek isolation from the masses. This reflects his belief in the importance of individuality and the potential conflict between innovative thinkers and societal norms.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: O sancta simplicitas! In what strange simplification and falsification man lives!
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche expresses amazement at the extent to which humans simplify and distort their understanding of reality. This exclamation introduces his critique of human knowledge and perception, suggesting that our view of the world is far from accurate.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: There are still harmless self-observers who believe that there are 'immediate certainties'; for instance, 'I think,' or as the superstition of Schopenhauer puts it, 'I will'
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche challenges the idea of 'immediate certainties' in philosophy, specifically targeting Descartes' 'I think' and Schopenhauer's 'I will'. He suggests that these supposedly self-evident truths are actually complex assumptions.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: It is WE alone who have devised cause, sequence, reciprocity, relativity, constraint, number, law, freedom, motive, and purpose; and when we interpret and intermix this symbol-world, as 'being-in-itself,' with things, we act once more as we have always acted--MYTHOLOGICALLY.
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche argues that many of our fundamental concepts about the world are human inventions rather than inherent features of reality. This challenges the objectivity of human knowledge and suggests that our understanding of the world is largely mythological.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: Gradually it has become clear to me what every great philosophy up till now has consisted of – namely, the confession of its originator, and a species of involuntary and unconscious auto-biography
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche suggests that all great philosophies are essentially personal expressions of their creators, rather than objective truths. This challenges the notion of philosophical objectivity and implies that understanding a philosophy requires understanding the philosopher's personal context.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: Whoever has endeavoured with some enigmatic longing, as I have, to think pessimism to its depths and to liberate it from the half-Christian, half-German narrowness and naivete with which it has finally presented itself to this century, namely, in the form of the Schopenhauerian philosophy
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche describes his attempt to explore pessimism more deeply, freeing it from its cultural and philosophical constraints. This reflects his critical approach to previous philosophical traditions and his desire to push thinking beyond conventional boundaries.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I
