quotes.text: What is it that forces us in general to the supposition that there is an essential opposition of 'true' and 'false'? Is it not enough to suppose degrees of seemingness, and as it were lighter and darker shades and tones of semblance
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche questions the traditional dichotomy between truth and falsehood, suggesting instead a spectrum of 'seemingness'. This challenges absolute notions of truth and introduces a more nuanced, perspectival view of reality.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: The genius of the heart, as that great mysterious one has it, the tempter-god and born rat-catcher of consciences, whose voice can descend into the nether-world of every soul
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche describes a 'genius of the heart', a metaphorical figure representing deep psychological insight. This reflects his interest in the hidden depths of the human psyche and the power of charismatic individuals to influence others.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: Every profound spirit needs a mask; nay, more, around every profound spirit there continually grows a mask, owing to the constantly false, that is to say, SUPERFICIAL interpretation of every word he utters
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche discusses the idea that deep thinkers often need to conceal their true nature, either deliberately or as a result of being misunderstood. This reflects his views on the isolation of great thinkers and the difficulty of communicating profound ideas.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: There is a stage of sleepiness in every suicide. The suicide does not want death - he wants a different life.
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche offers a psychological insight into suicide, suggesting it's not truly about wanting death, but about desiring a different life. This reflects his interest in the complex motivations behind human actions and the often misunderstood nature of extreme behaviors.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: The old theological problem of 'Faith' and 'Knowledge,' or more plainly, of instinct and reason--the question whether, in respect to the valuation of things, instinct deserves more authority than rationality
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche frames the conflict between faith and knowledge as a debate between instinct and reason. This reflects his interest in questioning traditional hierarchies of knowledge and his exploration of non-rational aspects of human nature.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: Supposing truth is a woman--what then? Are there not grounds for the suspicion that all philosophers, insofar as they were dogmatists, have been very inexpert about women?
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche uses a metaphor comparing truth to a woman to critique the approach of dogmatic philosophers. This reflects his skepticism towards absolute truth claims and his belief that traditional philosophy has been limited by its methods and assumptions.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: The greater the interest which a philosopher has been able to inspire, the more dangerous has everything become which he has taught as truth
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche suggests that the more influential a philosopher becomes, the more potentially harmful their ideas can be if taken as absolute truth. This reflects his wariness of dogmatism and his belief in the potentially dangerous power of ideas.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: There are few pains so grievous as to have seen, divined, or experienced how an exceptional man has missed his way and deteriorated
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche expresses the pain of witnessing a great individual's decline. This reflects his admiration for exceptional individuals and his concern with the challenges faced by those who deviate from societal norms.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: What serves the higher class of men for nourishment or refreshment, must be almost poison to an entirely different and lower order of human beings
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche suggests that what is beneficial for exceptional individuals might be harmful for the masses. This reflects his belief in fundamental differences between individuals and his critique of universal moral or intellectual standards.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: In our youthful years we still venerate and despise without the art of NUANCE, which is the best gain of life
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche reflects on the tendency of youth to see things in black and white, suggesting that the ability to perceive nuance is a valuable skill gained with maturity. This showcases his appreciation for complexity and subtlety in understanding.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: The intention as the sole origin and antecedent history of an action: under the influence of this prejudice moral praise and blame have been bestowed, and men have judged and even philosophized almost up to the present day
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche critiques the focus on intention in moral judgment, suggesting it's an oversimplification. This challenges traditional ethical theories and foreshadows more complex understandings of human behavior and morality.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: At whatever standpoint of philosophy one may place oneself nowadays, seen from every position, the ERRONEOUSNESS of the world in which we think we live is the surest and most certain thing our eyes can light upon
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche asserts that the incorrectness of our understanding of the world is the most certain thing we can know. This radical skepticism challenges conventional epistemology and suggests a fundamental limitation to human knowledge.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: The belief in 'immediate certainties' is a MORAL NAIVETE which does honour to us philosophers; but--we have now to cease being 'MERELY moral' men!
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche criticizes the philosophical belief in self-evident truths as a moral naivety. He suggests that philosophers need to move beyond conventional morality in their thinking, advocating for a more critical and nuanced approach.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: As regards materialistic atomism, it is one of the best-refuted theories that have been advanced
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche dismisses materialistic atomism as thoroughly debunked. This reflects his skepticism towards certain scientific theories and his belief that many widely accepted ideas are actually unsupported.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: The spectacle of the Tartuffery of old Kant, equally stiff and decent, with which he entices us into the dialectic by-ways that lead (more correctly mislead) to his 'categorical imperative'--makes us fastidious ones smile
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche criticizes Kant's approach to ethics, particularly his concept of the categorical imperative, as a form of deception. This reflects Nietzsche's skepticism towards traditional moral philosophy and his desire to expose hidden motivations.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: It is perhaps just dawning on five or six minds that natural philosophy is only a world-exposition and world-arrangement (according to us, if I may say so!) and NOT a world-explanation
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche suggests that natural philosophy (science) doesn't truly explain the world, but rather describes and organizes it according to human perspectives. This critiques scientific positivism and foreshadows later philosophies of science.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: The REAL philosophers, however, are COMMANDERS and law-givers; they say: 'Thus SHALL it be!' They determine first the Whither and the Why of mankind
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche describes his ideal of the philosopher as a creator of values rather than a mere observer or critic. This reflects his view of philosophy as an active, world-shaping endeavor rather than a passive, analytical one.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter II

quotes.text: There is, strictly speaking, neither unselfish conduct, nor a wholly disinterested point of view. Both are simply sublimations in which the basic element seems almost evaporated and betrays its presence only to the keenest observation
quotes.explanation: Nietzsche challenges the concepts of selflessness and objectivity, suggesting that all actions and viewpoints are ultimately rooted in self-interest. This reflects his skepticism towards altruism and his belief in the pervasive influence of personal motivations.
quotes.reference: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Nietzsche, Chapter I

quotes.text: Man is something that is to be surpassed. What have ye done to surpass man?
quotes.explanation: Zarathustra challenges humanity to strive for self-improvement and transcendence. This quote encapsulates Nietzsche's concept of the Übermensch or Superman, urging individuals to evolve beyond their current limitations.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 3: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I teach you the Superman. Man is something that is to be surpassed.
quotes.explanation: This quote directly introduces Nietzsche's concept of the Superman. It emphasizes the idea that human beings should continually strive to improve themselves and transcend their current state of being.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 3: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I conjure you, my brethren, REMAIN TRUE TO THE EARTH, and believe not those who speak unto you of superearthly hopes!
quotes.explanation: Zarathustra urges people to focus on the present, tangible world rather than abstract or otherworldly concepts. This reflects Nietzsche's emphasis on embracing life and rejecting escapist philosophies or religions.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 3: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love those that know not how to live except as down-goers, for they are the over-goers.
quotes.explanation: This paradoxical statement suggests that those who are willing to 'go down' or humble themselves in pursuit of growth are actually those who will ultimately transcend and overcome. It emphasizes the importance of struggle and self-sacrifice in personal development.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 4: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love him who liveth in order to know, and seeketh to know in order that the Superman may hereafter live. Thus seeketh he his own down-going.
quotes.explanation: This quote praises those who dedicate themselves to knowledge and understanding, not for personal gain, but for the betterment of future generations. It ties the pursuit of knowledge to the concept of the Superman.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 4: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love him whose soul is lavish, who wanteth no thanks and doth not give back: for he always bestoweth, and desireth not to keep for himself.
quotes.explanation: Zarathustra expresses admiration for those who give freely without expectation of return or recognition. This represents a selfless and abundant mindset, contrasting with more transactional views of human interaction.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 4: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love him who is ashamed when the dice fall in his favour, and who then asketh: 'Am I a dishonest player?'—for he is willing to succumb.
quotes.explanation: This quote praises those who question their own success and maintain high ethical standards even when it might be to their disadvantage. It emphasizes the importance of integrity and self-reflection.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 4: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love all who are like heavy drops falling one by one out of the dark cloud that lowereth over man: they herald the coming of the lightning, and succumb as heralds.
quotes.explanation: This metaphorical statement expresses admiration for those who pave the way for radical change or new ideas, even at great personal cost. It suggests that progress often requires sacrifice from visionaries.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 4: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: One must still have chaos in oneself to be able to give birth to a dancing star.
quotes.explanation: This poetic quote suggests that creativity and greatness often emerge from internal struggle or disorder. It encourages embracing one's inner complexity rather than seeking simple order or conformity.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 5: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: He who climbeth on the highest mountains, laugheth at all tragic plays and tragic realities.
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that achieving a higher perspective allows one to transcend the dramas and tragedies of everyday life. It encourages striving for a broader, more elevated viewpoint.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 7: Reading and Writing

quotes.text: What is the greatest thing ye can experience? It is the hour of great contempt.
quotes.explanation: Zarathustra posits that the moment of greatest revelation or growth comes when one fully recognizes and rejects the inadequacies of current human condition. This 'contempt' is seen as a catalyst for transformation and improvement.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 3: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I teach you the friend in whom the world standeth complete, a capsule of the good,—the creating friend, who hath always a complete world to bestow.
quotes.explanation: This quote presents an ideal of friendship as a creative and generous relationship. The true friend is seen as someone who enriches one's world and helps to realize one's potential.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter: The Friend

quotes.text: I am a railing alongside the torrent; whoever is able to grasp me may grasp me! Your crutch, however, I am not.
quotes.explanation: Zarathustra presents himself as a guide or support for those strong enough to keep up with him, but not as a crutch for the weak. This emphasizes personal responsibility and strength in one's own development.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter: The Pale Criminal

quotes.text: The superman is the meaning of the earth. Let your will say: The superman SHALL BE the meaning of the earth!
quotes.explanation: This quote reiterates the centrality of the Superman concept in Zarathustra's philosophy. It calls for humanity to dedicate itself to the goal of producing higher, more evolved individuals as the ultimate purpose of earthly existence.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 3: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: Man is a rope stretched between the animal and the Superman—a rope over an abyss.
quotes.explanation: This metaphor portrays humanity as a transitional state between our animal origins and the potential Superman. It emphasizes both the precariousness and the potential of the human condition.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 4: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I say unto you: one must still have chaos in oneself to be able to give birth to a dancing star. I say unto you: ye have still chaos in yourselves.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the creative potential of inner turmoil and uncertainty. It suggests that greatness emerges from embracing one's inner chaos rather than seeking to eliminate it entirely.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 5: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: Ye have made your way from the worm to man, and much within you is still worm. Once were ye apes, and even yet man is more of an ape than any of the apes.
quotes.explanation: This provocative statement challenges human pride by reminding us of our evolutionary origins. It suggests that humanity still has much evolving to do to reach its full potential.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 3: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: To live is to suffer, to survive is to find some meaning in the suffering.
quotes.explanation: This quote acknowledges the inherent difficulties of life while suggesting that the key to survival is finding purpose or meaning within that struggle.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra

quotes.text: The higher we soar the smaller we appear to those who cannot fly.
quotes.explanation: This metaphorical statement suggests that as individuals grow and achieve, they may become incomprehensible or appear diminished to those who haven't undergone similar development.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra

quotes.text: He who would learn to fly one day must first learn to stand and walk and run and climb and dance; one cannot fly into flying.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the importance of gradual progress and mastering fundamentals before attempting more advanced achievements. It advocates for patience and systematic development.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra

quotes.text: Become who you are!
quotes.explanation: This concise but powerful statement encapsulates the idea of self-realization and authenticity. It encourages individuals to fully embrace and develop their unique potential.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra

quotes.text: The proudest animal under the sun, and the wisest animal under the sun,—they have come out to reconnoitre.
quotes.explanation: This quote refers to the eagle and the serpent, symbols of pride and wisdom respectively. It suggests the importance of balancing these qualities in the pursuit of self-overcoming.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 10: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love him who desireth not too many virtues. One virtue is more of a virtue than two, because it is more of a knot for one's destiny to cling to.
quotes.explanation: This quote advocates for focused self-improvement rather than trying to excel in too many areas. It suggests that mastery of one virtue is more impactful than mediocrity in many.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 4: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: What is great in man is that he is a bridge and not a goal.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the transitional nature of humanity, viewing humans not as an end point but as a means to something greater (the Superman). It encourages constant growth and evolution.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra

quotes.text: I love those who do not first seek a reason beyond the stars for going down and being sacrifices, but sacrifice themselves to the earth, that the earth of the Superman may hereafter arrive.
quotes.explanation: This quote praises those who dedicate themselves to earthly improvement rather than seeking otherworldly justifications. It emphasizes the importance of present action for future evolution.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 4: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I teach you the friend and his overflowing heart. But one must know how to be a sponge if one wants to be loved by overflowing hearts.
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that to truly engage in deep friendships or love, one must be open and receptive to others, able to absorb and appreciate their abundance of spirit.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra

quotes.text: The soul which hath the longest ladder, and can go deepest down: how could there not be most parasites upon it?
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that those with the greatest potential or who have achieved the most are often subject to the most criticism or exploitation. It implies that facing opposition is a sign of significance.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra

quotes.text: I change too quickly: my to-day refuteth my yesterday. When I ascend I often leap over steps, and no step forgiveth me that.
quotes.explanation: This quote acknowledges the rapid personal growth that can occur in self-development. It also notes that such quick changes can be disorienting and may not be easily accepted by others.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 8: The Tree on the Hill

quotes.text: Blessed are the sleepy ones: for they shall soon fall off.
quotes.explanation: This ironic statement criticizes those who are not fully engaged with life or self-improvement. It suggests that such individuals will naturally be left behind in the process of human evolution.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 2: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: Verily, a polluted stream is man. One must be a sea to be able to receive a polluted stream without becoming unclean.
quotes.explanation: This metaphor suggests that to engage with the complexities and imperfections of humanity without being corrupted, one must have great capacity and depth, like the sea.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 3: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love him whose soul is overfull, so that he forgetteth himself, and all things are in him: thus all things become his down-going.
quotes.explanation: This quote praises those who are so filled with life and potential that they transcend self-concern. It suggests that this state of abundance leads to a kind of self-overcoming.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Chapter 4: Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: And once you are awake, you shall remain awake eternally.
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that once one achieves a higher state of consciousness or understanding, there's no going back to ignorance. It emphasizes the transformative nature of enlightenment.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Vision and the Riddle

quotes.text: The spirit now wills his own will, and he who had been lost to the world now conquers the world.
quotes.explanation: This quote speaks to the power of self-determination and how embracing one's own will can lead to mastery over one's circumstances.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Three Metamorphoses

quotes.text: I love him who maketh his virtue his inclination and destiny: thus, for the sake of his virtue, he is willing to live on, or live no more.
quotes.explanation: This quote praises those who fully embody their values, to the point where their virtues become inseparable from their identity and purpose in life.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: Behold, I teach you the overman: he is this lightning, he is this madness!
quotes.explanation: Zarathustra likens the concept of the overman (or superman) to lightning and madness, suggesting that this ideal represents a radical, energetic break from conventional human limitations.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: You must be ready to burn yourself in your own flame; how could you rise anew if you have not first become ashes?
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the necessity of self-destruction or radical transformation as a prerequisite for personal growth and renewal.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Way of the Creator

quotes.text: And if a friend does you wrong, then say: 'I forgive you what you have done unto me; that you have done it unto yourself, however—how could I forgive that?'
quotes.explanation: This quote offers a nuanced view on forgiveness, suggesting that while we can forgive actions against ourselves, we cannot absolve others of the harm they do to themselves through their actions.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Friend

quotes.text: Is not the forest silent? And the trees, are they not the most discreet of confidants?
quotes.explanation: This quote highlights the value of solitude and communion with nature for self-reflection and personal growth.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Forest

quotes.text: Silence is worse; all truths that are kept silent become poisonous.
quotes.explanation: This quote warns against the dangers of suppressing truth, suggesting that unspoken truths can become harmful or toxic over time.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Flies of the Market-Place

quotes.text: The loneliest one offers his hand too quickly to whomever he encounters.
quotes.explanation: This quote cautions against the tendency of lonely individuals to form hasty or superficial connections out of desperation for companionship.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Friend

quotes.text: Companions, the creator seeks, not corpses, not herds and believers. Fellow creators, the creator seeks—those who write new values on new tablets.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes Zarathustra's desire for active, creative individuals who can help shape new values and ideas, rather than passive followers.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love him who justifieth the future ones, and redeemeth the past ones: for he is willing to succumb through the present ones.
quotes.explanation: This quote praises those who can reconcile the past and future, even at the cost of present difficulties, suggesting a long-term, holistic view of human progress.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: Alas, there cometh the time when man will no longer give birth to any star.
quotes.explanation: This quote expresses concern about a future where humanity loses its capacity for greatness or transcendent achievement.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: One repays a teacher badly if one always remains nothing but a pupil.
quotes.explanation: This quote encourages individuals to grow beyond their teachers and develop their own ideas, rather than remaining perpetual students.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Gift-Giving Virtue

quotes.text: And we should consider every day lost on which we have not danced at least once.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the importance of joy, celebration, and physical expression in daily life.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On Reading and Writing

quotes.text: The great epochs of our life come when we gain the courage to rechristen our evil as what is best in us.
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that personal growth often involves reinterpreting aspects of ourselves that we once considered negative, recognizing their potential value.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Way of the Creator

quotes.text: The hermit does not believe that a philosopher—supposing that a philosopher has always been first of all a hermit—ever expressed his actual and ultimate opinions in books.
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that true wisdom or profound thoughts may not always be fully captured in written works, and that solitude is crucial for deep philosophical insight.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Spirit of Gravity

quotes.text: He who cannot command himself should obey. And many can command themselves, but much is still lacking before they can obey themselves.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the importance of self-discipline and the challenge of truly following one's own principles and decisions.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On Self-Overcoming

quotes.text: The devil is an optimist if he thinks he can make people worse than they are.
quotes.explanation: This humorous quote suggests a complex view of human nature, implying that people might already embody the worst possible state, leaving no room for further corruption.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Higher Man

quotes.text: The true man wants two things: danger and play. For that reason he wants woman, as the most dangerous plaything.
quotes.explanation: This provocative quote, reflective of Nietzsche's era, suggests that the ideal man seeks both risk and enjoyment, viewing relationships as a form of exciting challenge.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On Little Old and Young Women

quotes.text: In truth, I have often laughed at the weaklings who thought themselves good because they had no claws.
quotes.explanation: This quote criticizes those who equate weakness or inability to act with moral goodness, suggesting that true virtue requires strength and capability.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Tarantulas

quotes.text: And lost be the day to us in which a measure hath not been danced. And false be every truth which hath not had laughter along with it!
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the importance of joy, celebration, and humor in life, suggesting that even truth is incomplete without laughter.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On Reading and Writing

quotes.text: Ye look aloft when ye long for exaltation, and I look downward because I am exalted.
quotes.explanation: This quote contrasts Zarathustra's perspective with common attitudes, suggesting that true elevation involves a comprehensive view that includes looking 'downward' as well as upward.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On Reading and Writing

quotes.text: I love those who do not first seek behind the stars for a reason to go under and be sacrifice, but who sacrifice themselves for the earth, that the earth may some day become the overman's.
quotes.explanation: This quote praises those who dedicate themselves to earthly improvement rather than seeking otherworldly justifications, emphasizing the importance of present action for future evolution.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love him who reserveth no share of spirit for himself, but wanteth to be wholly the spirit of his virtue: thus walketh he as spirit over the bridge.
quotes.explanation: This quote admires those who fully embody their virtues, suggesting that complete dedication to one's principles allows for transcendence.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: Alas! There cometh the time when man will no longer launch the arrow of his longing beyond man — and the string of his bow will have unlearned to whizz!
quotes.explanation: This quote expresses concern about a future where humanity loses its capacity for aspiration and self-transcendence.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love him who liveth in order to know, and seeketh to know in order that the overman may hereafter live.
quotes.explanation: This quote praises those who pursue knowledge not for its own sake, but as a means to elevate humanity and pave the way for the overman.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love him who chasteneth his God, because he loveth his God: for he must succumb through the wrath of his God.
quotes.explanation: This quote admires those who challenge their beliefs out of devotion, suggesting that true faith involves critical engagement rather than blind acceptance.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I love all who are like heavy drops falling one by one out of the dark cloud that lowereth over man: they herald the coming of the lightning, and succumb as heralds.
quotes.explanation: This metaphorical statement expresses admiration for those who pave the way for radical change or new ideas, even at great personal cost.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: I teach you the friend in whom the world standeth complete, a capsule of the good,—the creating friend, who hath always a complete world to bestow.
quotes.explanation: This quote presents an ideal of friendship as a creative and generous relationship, where the friend enriches one's world and helps to realize one's potential.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Friend

quotes.text: Untroubled, scornful, outrageous—that is how wisdom wants us to be: she is a woman and never loves anyone but a warrior.
quotes.explanation: This quote personifies wisdom as demanding courage and a willingness to challenge norms, suggesting that true understanding requires a warrior-like spirit.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On Reading and Writing

quotes.text: Your soul will be dead even sooner than your body: fear nothing any more!
quotes.explanation: This quote challenges the fear of physical death by suggesting that spiritual or intellectual stagnation is a more immediate concern.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: One must learn to love oneself with a wholesome and healthy love, so that one can bear to be with oneself and need not roam.
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the importance of self-love and self-acceptance as a foundation for personal stability and growth.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Spirit of Gravity

quotes.text: Nobody is free to be a crab without becoming a crab.
quotes.explanation: This metaphorical statement suggests that our choices and actions inevitably shape our identity, warning against adopting negative behaviors.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Spirit of Gravity

quotes.text: The real man wants two different things: danger and play. For that reason he wants woman, as the most dangerous plaything.
quotes.explanation: This provocative quote, reflective of Nietzsche's era, suggests that relationships involve both risk and enjoyment, viewing them as a form of exciting challenge.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On Little Old and Young Women

quotes.text: The child is innocence and forgetting, a new beginning, a game, a self-rolling wheel, a first movement, a sacred 'Yes.'
quotes.explanation: This quote describes the child-like state as an ideal of renewal and affirmation, free from the burdens of past knowledge and inhibitions.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Three Metamorphoses

quotes.text: I love those who do not first seek behind the stars for a reason to go under and be sacrifice, but who sacrifice themselves for the earth, that the earth may some day become the overman's.
quotes.explanation: This quote praises those who dedicate themselves to earthly improvement rather than seeking otherworldly justifications, emphasizing the importance of present action for future evolution.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Zarathustra's Prologue

quotes.text: And lost be the day to us in which a measure hath not been danced. And false be every truth which hath not had laughter along with it!
quotes.explanation: This quote emphasizes the importance of joy, celebration, and humor in life, suggesting that even truth is incomplete without laughter.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On Reading and Writing

quotes.text: Ye look aloft when ye long for exaltation, and I look downward because I am exalted.
quotes.explanation: This quote contrasts Zarathustra's perspective with common attitudes, suggesting that true elevation involves a comprehensive view that includes looking 'downward' as well as upward.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On Reading and Writing

quotes.text: To be the child who is newly born, the creator must also want to be the mother who gives birth and the pangs of the birth-giver.
quotes.explanation: This quote suggests that true creativity and self-renewal involve not just the joy of new beginnings, but also the pain and effort of bringing something new into existence.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Way of the Creator

quotes.text: Devise the love that bears not only all punishment but also all guilt!
quotes.explanation: This quote challenges conventional notions of love, suggesting a form of love that is strong enough to encompass both the consequences of actions and the responsibility for them.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, On the Way of the Creator

quotes.text: One, is always too many about me—thinketh the anchorite. Always once one—that maketh two in the long run!
quotes.explanation: This quote reflects on the nature of solitude and self-reflection. It suggests that even in isolation, one's thoughts create a form of company, emphasizing the complexity of true solitude.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: Our faith in others betrayeth wherein we would fain have faith in ourselves. Our longing for a friend is our betrayer.
quotes.explanation: This insight suggests that our desire for friendship often stems from our own insecurities and lack of self-faith. It encourages introspection and self-reliance.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: If one would have a friend, then must one also be willing to wage war for him: and in order to wage war, one must be CAPABLE of being an enemy.
quotes.explanation: Zarathustra emphasizes that true friendship requires strength and the ability to face conflict. It suggests that genuine relationships involve both support and challenge.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: In one's friend one shall have one's best enemy. Thou shalt be closest unto him with thy heart when thou withstandest him.
quotes.explanation: This paradoxical statement suggests that true friendship involves challenging each other. It encourages growth through opposition and honest interaction.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: He who maketh no secret of himself shocketh: so much reason have ye to fear nakedness!
quotes.explanation: This quote reflects on the fear of vulnerability and authenticity. It suggests that society often fears those who are truly open and honest about themselves.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: Ye cannot endure it with yourselves, and do not love yourselves sufficiently: so ye seek to mislead your neighbour into love, and would fain gild yourselves with his error.
quotes.explanation: Zarathustra criticizes those who seek validation from others due to lack of self-love. It encourages self-acceptance rather than seeking affirmation externally.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: Not the height, it is the declivity that is terrible!
quotes.explanation: This metaphor suggests that the fear of falling or failing is often more terrifying than the challenge of climbing. It speaks to the psychological aspects of ambition and risk.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: To man clingeth my will; with chains do I bind myself to man, because I am pulled upwards to the Superman: for thither doth mine other will tend.
quotes.explanation: Zarathustra expresses his connection to humanity while aspiring towards the concept of the Superman. It reflects the tension between current reality and future potential.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: And he who would not languish amongst men, must learn to drink out of all glasses; and he who would keep clean amongst men, must know how to wash himself even with dirty water.
quotes.explanation: This metaphorical advice suggests adaptability and resilience in dealing with various life situations, even unpleasant ones.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: Is not wounded vanity the mother of all tragedies?
quotes.explanation: This question suggests that many conflicts and sorrows stem from hurt pride rather than substantive issues. It encourages reflection on the root of personal and social problems.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: That life may be fair to behold, its game must be well played; for that purpose, however, it needeth good actors.
quotes.explanation: This metaphor compares life to a performance, suggesting that to make life beautiful, one must engage fully and skillfully in its challenges and opportunities.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: And if that be the true virtue which is unconscious of itself—well, the vain man is unconscious of his modesty!
quotes.explanation: This paradoxical statement humorously suggests that even vanity can be a form of unconscious virtue, challenging conventional notions of modesty and self-awareness.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: Verily, there is still a future even for evil!
quotes.explanation: This provocative statement suggests that even negative aspects of existence have potential for transformation or purpose, encouraging a broader perspective on morality and change.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: For that the Superman may not lack his dragon, the superdragon that is worthy of him, there must still much warm sun glow on moist virgin forests!
quotes.explanation: This metaphorical statement suggests that great challenges are necessary for the development of exceptional individuals. It implies that adversity and untamed potential are crucial for growth.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: Ah, I became tired of those highest and best ones: from their 'height' did I long to be up, out, and away to the Superman!
quotes.explanation: Zarathustra expresses dissatisfaction with current ideals of excellence, aspiring instead to a higher concept of human potential embodied in the Superman.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: A horror came over me when I saw those best ones naked: then there grew for me the pinions to soar away into distant futures.
quotes.explanation: This vivid imagery expresses disillusionment with current ideals, leading to a desire for radical new possibilities and futures.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: Into more distant futures, into more southern souths than ever artist dreamed of: thither, where Gods are ashamed of all clothes!
quotes.explanation: This poetic expression conveys a longing for radical new ways of thinking and being, beyond current moral and artistic limitations.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Manly Prudence

quotes.text: Too far did I fly into the future: a horror seized upon me.
quotes.explanation: This statement reflects the unsettling nature of visionary thinking. It suggests that glimpsing radical future possibilities can be both exhilarating and terrifying.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Land of Culture

quotes.text: And when I looked around me, lo! there time was my sole contemporary.
quotes.explanation: This poetic observation conveys a sense of profound isolation in one's vision or understanding. It suggests that truly original thought can separate one from their contemporaries.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Land of Culture

quotes.text: Written all over with the characters of the past, and these characters also pencilled over with new characters—thus have ye concealed yourselves well from all decipherers!
quotes.explanation: This metaphor criticizes the complexity and inauthenticity of modern culture, suggesting that people hide their true selves behind layers of historical and contemporary influences.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Land of Culture

quotes.text: Thoughts that come with doves' footsteps guide the world.
quotes.explanation: This beautiful metaphor suggests that the most profound and influential ideas often come quietly and subtly, rather than with force or fanfare.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Stillest Hour

quotes.text: O Zarathustra, thou shalt go as a shadow of that which is to come: thus wilt thou command, and in commanding go foremost.
quotes.explanation: This guidance suggests that true leadership involves embodying and foreshadowing future potentials, rather than merely directing based on current realities.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Stillest Hour

quotes.text: Thou must yet become a child, and be without shame.
quotes.explanation: This advice encourages embracing a child-like perspective, free from societal constraints and self-consciousness, to achieve new insights and ways of being.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Stillest Hour

quotes.text: The pride of youth is still upon thee; late hast thou become young: but he who would become a child must surmount even his youth.
quotes.explanation: This paradoxical statement suggests that true wisdom involves moving beyond both the constraints of maturity and the limitations of youth, to achieve a more fundamental openness to experience.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Stillest Hour

quotes.text: O Zarathustra, thy fruits are ripe, but thou art not ripe for thy fruits!
quotes.explanation: This metaphorical statement suggests that one's ideas or potential may be fully developed, but personal readiness to manifest them may lag behind, encouraging patience and further personal growth.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Stillest Hour

quotes.text: So must thou go again into solitude: for thou shalt yet become mellow.
quotes.explanation: This advice emphasizes the importance of periods of solitude and reflection for personal growth and the full realization of one's potential.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Stillest Hour

quotes.text: To stand with relaxed muscles and with unharnessed will: that is the hardest for all of you, ye sublime ones!
quotes.explanation: This observation suggests that true mastery involves a state of relaxed readiness, rather than constant tension or effort. It encourages a balance of strength and ease.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Sublime Ones

quotes.text: When power becometh gracious and descendeth into the visible—I call such condescension, beauty.
quotes.explanation: This definition of beauty connects it with the graceful expression of power, suggesting that true beauty involves strength expressed with subtlety and benevolence.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Sublime Ones

quotes.text: For this is the secret of the soul: when the hero hath abandoned it, then only approacheth it in dreams—the superhero.
quotes.explanation: This cryptic statement suggests that the highest potentials often reveal themselves only when one has moved beyond conventional notions of heroism or achievement.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Sublime Ones

quotes.text: Hungry, fierce, lonesome, God-forsaken: so doth the lion-will wish itself.
quotes.explanation: This vivid description characterizes the will of a truly independent and powerful individual, emphasizing the often solitary and challenging nature of pursuing one's highest potential.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Famous Wise Ones

quotes.text: The friend of the anchorite is always the third one: the third one is the cork which preventeth the conversation of the two sinking into the depth.
quotes.explanation: This metaphorical statement suggests that in deep, intimate conversations, a third party often serves to keep the exchange from becoming too intense or overwhelming.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: In one's friend one shall have one's best enemy. Thou shalt be closest unto him with thy heart when thou withstandest him.
quotes.explanation: This paradoxical advice suggests that true friendship involves challenging each other, implying that opposition can be a form of closeness and support.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: Let thy pity be a divining: to know first if thy friend wanteth pity. Perhaps he loveth in thee the unmoved eye, and the look of eternity.
quotes.explanation: This insight advises caution in offering pity, suggesting that sometimes what a friend needs is not sympathy but a steady, unperturbed perspective.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: Art thou pure air and solitude and bread and medicine to thy friend? Many a one cannot loosen his own fetters, but is nevertheless his friend's emancipator.
quotes.explanation: This question encourages one to be a source of nourishment and freedom for friends, while acknowledging that we might help others in ways we can't help ourselves.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: Art thou a slave? Then thou canst not be a friend. Art thou a tyrant? Then thou canst not have friends.
quotes.explanation: This statement suggests that true friendship requires a balance of independence and respect, incompatible with either subservience or domination.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: In woman's love there is injustice and blindness to all she doth not love. And even in woman's conscious love, there is still always surprise and lightning and night, along with the light.
quotes.explanation: This complex view of women's love suggests it contains both unfairness and wonder, emphasizing its intense and unpredictable nature.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: As yet woman is not capable of friendship: women are still cats, and birds. Or at the best, cows.
quotes.explanation: This controversial statement reflects dated views on gender, suggesting women are not yet capable of the kind of friendship Zarathustra envisions.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: Ye have not yet suffered MEN. Had ye suffered as men, then would ye know how to be my friends.
quotes.explanation: This suggests that deep friendship requires a shared experience of profound suffering or challenge, particularly in a masculine context.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Friend

quotes.text: Verily, I have often laughed at the weaklings, who think themselves good because they have crippled paws!
quotes.explanation: This satirical observation critiques those who mistake weakness for virtue, suggesting that true goodness requires strength and capability.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Sublime Ones

quotes.text: The virtue of the pillar shalt thou strive after: more beautiful doth it ever become, and more graceful—but internally harder and more sustaining—the higher it riseth.
quotes.explanation: This metaphor encourages personal growth that combines external grace with internal strength, suggesting that true elevation requires both aesthetic and structural improvement.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Sublime Ones

quotes.text: Verily, a prodigy is this power of praising and blaming. Tell me, ye brethren, who will master it for me? Who will put a fetter upon the thousand necks of this animal?
quotes.explanation: This questions the power of judgment and valuation, suggesting it's a formidable force that needs to be mastered or constrained.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Thousand and One Goals

quotes.text: A thousand goals have there been hitherto, for a thousand peoples have there been. Only the fetter for the thousand necks is still lacking; there is lacking the one goal. As yet humanity hath not a goal.
quotes.explanation: This observation suggests that while many cultures have had their own goals, humanity as a whole lacks a unified purpose or direction.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Thousand and One Goals

quotes.text: Higher than love to your neighbour is love to the furthest and future ones; higher still than love to men, is love to things and phantoms.
quotes.explanation: This hierarchy of love prioritizes abstract and future-oriented love over immediate, personal love, encouraging a broader perspective on affection and commitment.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Neighbour-Love

quotes.text: The furthest ones are they who pay for your love to the near ones; and when there are but five of you together, a sixth must always die.
quotes.explanation: This cryptic statement suggests that love for those close to us often comes at the expense of those distant, implying a necessary sacrifice in our affections.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Neighbour-Love

quotes.text: Not the neighbour do I teach you, but the friend. Let the friend be the festival of the earth to you, and a foretaste of the Superman.
quotes.explanation: This elevates the concept of friendship above mere neighborly relations, presenting it as a joyous and transformative relationship that hints at greater human potential.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: Neighbour-Love

quotes.text: Wouldst thou go into isolation, my brother? Wouldst thou seek the way unto thyself? Tarry yet a little and hearken unto me.
quotes.explanation: This introduces the theme of self-discovery through isolation, while also cautioning against hasty retreat from society.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Way of the Creating One

quotes.text: Free from what? What doth that matter to Zarathustra! Clearly, however, shall thine eye show unto me: free FOR WHAT?
quotes.explanation: This challenges the concept of freedom, suggesting that what one is free for is more important than what one is free from, emphasizing purpose over mere liberation.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Way of the Creating One

quotes.text: Canst thou give unto thyself thy bad and thy good, and set up thy will as a law over thee? Canst thou be judge for thyself, and avenger of thy law?
quotes.explanation: This series of questions emphasizes the importance of self-governance and personal moral autonomy, challenging the individual to create and uphold their own values.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Way of the Creating One

quotes.text: Terrible is aloneness with the judge and avenger of one's own law. Thus is a star projected into desert space, and into the icy breath of aloneness.
quotes.explanation: This vivid metaphor describes the challenging nature of true moral autonomy, likening it to the isolation of a star in space, emphasizing both its grandeur and its difficulty.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Way of the Creating One

quotes.text: How could ye be just unto me! - must thou say - I choose your injustice as my allotted portion.
quotes.explanation: This paradoxical statement suggests embracing others' misjudgments as a chosen burden, implying that true self-understanding may often be at odds with others' perceptions.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Way of the Creating One

quotes.text: A heretic wilt thou be to thyself, and a wizard and a soothsayer, and a fool, and a doubter, and a reprobate, and a villain.
quotes.explanation: This list of roles encourages embracing various, often negatively perceived identities in the process of self-discovery and creation.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Way of the Creating One

quotes.text: Ready must thou be to burn thyself in thine own flame; how couldst thou become new if thou have not first become ashes!
quotes.explanation: This metaphor of self-immolation emphasizes the need for radical self-transformation, suggesting that renewal requires the destruction of one's former self.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Way of the Creating One

quotes.text: Man is a rope stretched between the animal and the Superman—a rope over an abyss.
quotes.explanation: This vivid metaphor presents humanity as a transitional state, emphasizing both the potential for growth and the precariousness of our current condition.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Old and Young Women

quotes.text: Everything in woman is a riddle, and everything in woman hath one solution—it is called pregnancy.
quotes.explanation: This controversial statement reduces the complexity of womanhood to the capacity for childbearing, reflecting dated and limited views on gender.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Old and Young Women

quotes.text: Man shall be trained for war, and woman for the recreation of the warrior: all else is folly.
quotes.explanation: This statement presents a highly gendered and controversial view of social roles, reducing men and women to warlike and supportive functions respectively.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Old and Young Women

quotes.text: Let man fear woman when she loveth: then maketh she every sacrifice, and everything else she regardeth as worthless.
quotes.explanation: This portrays women's love as all-consuming and potentially dangerous, suggesting it leads to extreme sacrifice and disregard for other values.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Old and Young Women

quotes.text: The happiness of man is, 'I will.' The happiness of woman is, 'He will.'
quotes.explanation: This controversial statement presents a stark gender divide in the nature of happiness, associating male fulfillment with agency and female fulfillment with acquiescence.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Old and Young Women

quotes.text: Obey, must the woman, and find a depth for her surface. Surface, is woman's soul, a mobile, stormy film on shallow water.
quotes.explanation: This highly controversial characterization of women suggests a lack of depth and a need for subservience, reflecting deeply problematic gender views.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Old and Young Women

quotes.text: Thou goest to women? Do not forget thy whip!
quotes.explanation: This infamous quote, presented as advice from an old woman, suggests a deeply problematic view of gender relations involving domination and control.
quotes.reference: Thus Spoke Zarathustra, Part II: The Old and Young Women
